{{marriage|Eleanor Brown|1937|1946}} | children = Elliot Brown | yearsactive = 1912â€“1946 }} '''George Joseph Somerville''' (July 10, 1892 – January 5, 1946), known professionally as '''Slim Summerville''', was an American [[film actor]], best known as a [[comedy]] [[performer]].{{cite book | first=Ray | last=Stuart | title=Immortals of the Screen | page=218 | publisher=Sherbourne Press | year=1965}} ==Life== Born George Joseph Somerville in [[Albuquerque, New Mexico]], his mother died when he was five.{{cite news |title=Sad-Looking Slim Summerville Never Hoped To Be Funny - Just Can't Help It |first=Paul |last=Harrison |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=bnYbAAAAIBAJ&sjid=1ksEAAAAIBAJ&pg=3961,5297533&dq=slim+summerville&hl=en |newspaper=The Pittsburgh Press |date=13 July 1936 |accessdate=8 February 2012}} Moving from [[New Mexico]] to Canada to [[Oklahoma]], he had a [[nomad]]ic upbringing. He married Gertrude Martha Roell on 19 November 1927.{{cite news |title=Sad Slim Summerville Loses Wife at Court |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=BChWAAAAIBAJ&sjid=r-MDAAAAIBAJ&pg=4465,534233&dq=slim+and+summerville+and+divorce&hl=en |newspaper=The Spokesman-Review |date=2 October 1936 |accessdate=10 February 2012}} In early 1932, the Summervilles adopted a four-week-old baby boy whom they christened Elliott George.{{cite news |title=Slum Summerville of Movies Adopts Baby |url=http://hollywoodheyday.blogspot.com/2008/10/february-6-1932.html |newspaper=Associated Press |date=6 February 1932 |accessdate=9 February 2012}} The couple divorced in September 1936,{{cite news |title=Wife Divorces Film Comedian |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=jXYbAAAAIBAJ&sjid=0ksEAAAAIBAJ&pg=4438,1061328&dq=slim+and+summerville+and+elliot+and+george&hl=en |newspaper=The Pittsburgh Press |date=2 October 1936 |accessdate=10 February 2012}} and he then married Eleanor Brown (also a divorcee), who was his nurse, who cared for him when he was sick. She fell in love and married him in 1937, to keep him from getting sick again. Summerville died of a [[stroke]] on January 5, 1946 in [[Laguna Beach, California]].{{cite journal | journal=Motion Picture Herald | publisher=Quigley Pub. Co. | year=1946}} He is buried at [[Inglewood Park Cemetery]] in [[South Los Angeles]] community of [[Inglewood, California]]. Twenty years after his death, his beach front house on Sleepy Hollow Lane in Laguna Beach was converted into the Beach House restaurant,{{cite book | title=Life is a beach: a vacationer's guide to the West Coast | first1=Parke | last1=Puterbaugh | first2=Alan | last2=Bisbort | publisher=McGraw-Hill | year=1988 | page=74}} now the Driftwood Kitchen.{{Cite web|url=http://www.yelp.com/biz/driftwood-kitchen-laguna-beach-2|title=Driftwood Kitchen - Laguna Beach, CA|website=Yelp|access-date=2016-05-22}} ==Career== Summerville's first [[Job (role)|job]] was as a [[Courier|messenger]] for the [[Canadian Pacific Railway#Telegraph|Canadian Pacific Telegraphs]] in [[Chatham, Ontario]] where he lived with his [[English people|English]] [[grandparents]].{{cite news |title=Lanky Screen Comic Gets Romantic 'Break' |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=eHYtAAAAIBAJ&sjid=i5gFAAAAIBAJ&pg=5799,2888429&dq=slim+and+summerville+and+eleanor&hl=en |newspaper=The Montreal Gazette |date=17 September 1941 |accessdate=10 February 2012}} He was working as a [[poolroom]] [[porter (carrier)|porter]] when found by [[Edgar Kennedy]],{{cite news |title=Stroke Fatal to Movie Star - "Slim" Summerville Dies Suddenly |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=6x5HAAAAIBAJ&sjid=nXoMAAAAIBAJ&pg=3639,349976&dq=slim+summerville+dies&hl=en |newspaper=Warsaw Daily Union |date=7 January 1946 |accessdate=8 February 2012}} who took him to [[Mack Sennett]] where he started at $3.50 per day.{{cite news |title=Slim Summerville, Of The Movies, Dies |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=SOMcAAAAIBAJ&sjid=mWQEAAAAIBAJ&pg=2978,443417&dq=slim+summerville&hl=en |newspaper=Sarasota Herald-Tribune |date=7 January 1946 |accessdate=8 February 2012}} His first role was as a "[[Keystone Kops|Keystone Kop]]" in ''[[Hoffmeyer's Legacy]]'' (1912). His tall, gangly appearance was well utilized in numerous short [[comedy films]] during the [[silent film]] era, and in addition to his many acting roles, he directed more than 50 [[short films]]. Occasionally, he played in dramatic films, such as ''[[All Quiet on the Western Front (1930 film)|All Quiet on the Western Front]]'' (1930) and ''[[Jesse James (1939 film)|Jesse James]]'' (1939). However, he was most successful in comedy films, including several with [[ZaSu Pitts]]. He also played in films with [[Shirley Temple]], ''[[Captain January (1936 film)|Captain January]]'' (1936) and ''[[Rebecca of Sunnybrook Farm (1938 film)|Rebecca of Sunnybrook Farm]]'' (1938). ==Legacy== For his contribution to the motion picture industry, Slim Summerville has a star on the [[Hollywood Walk of Fame]] at 6409 Hollywood Blvd.[http://www.walkoffame.com/slim-summerville Slim Summerville]. ''[[Hollywood Walk of Fame]]''.
